SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES,
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.
Your full name ____________________________
Present Address ____________________________
Pioneer Address ____________________________
Year you came to Saskatchewan ______________

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORHOOD VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first five years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth in the second five years?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? What was the reason for these visits?

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days? How often?

4. Were you often invited to dinner parties, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

5. What time of the day did you go, in the morning and evening, or in the afternoon?

6. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

7. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come other expression (that is, was the term to make polite used, or was some other expression used)?

8. If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

9. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the plants?

10. Did you ever have "meets" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make butter, or clean clothes?

11. Tell me something about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling where they were held, and for whom they occurred.

12. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, first drives, or dances in town? Describe.

13. Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

14. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going to town from one house to another at definite times—every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.)?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, plantings, etc.) If you have not described these in the School Questionnaire, give dates.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? How large was it?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social entertainments and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, how often did you go to the school house for district gatherings and other uses?)

10. What parties were held in the hall? (Refer to question 8, 9, and 10 all the parties listed.)

How were boys and girls children provided for?

How were boys and girls children provided for?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the house or for community gatherings? Explain.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the chivalry known in your community? Describe what you remember about chivalry, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popularly indulged at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization. Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? How many women belonged? How often did it meet? What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services. They have helped all food causes, the Red Cross, Better Living and Better Nutrition (1930's) and food and clothing for the destitute classes.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (sex, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church records book for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? They played the same games as only children do today.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, its purpose (can women, young people), whether it included particularly the Negro race, or was centered in the very small area (for example within a school district), or was connected with the church, villages, and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church, villages, and included the surrounding community, so they need not be included.)

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? What rooms were used?

20. Have you attended or participated in General Information Lectures, talks or foreign bands, etc.? If so, where did you attend them?

21. What games did boys play in summer (jump rope, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? What games did girls play in summer (jump rope, ball, marbles, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 
   The only outdoor game I remember was "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games? 
   Were all played, also "Old Maid".

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? 
   Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
The first picnic took place in the Wake beautiful
place a short time ago. We started early in the morning
with a breakfast at the hotel. We then proceeded to
the lake. The weather was perfect and the
weather was very pleasant. We had a lovely
lunch made by Mrs. Smith. After lunch we had
a wonderful time. We played games and
enjoyed each other's company. It was a
wonderful day and we all had a great time.

June 9th, 1875

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? Mr. Bump brought some flutes and a piano.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Mr. Reed had a fiddle and a banjo.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them. We bought a harmonica.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes. When was it started? 1916.

Who started it? Mr. J.B. Foster.

How long did it continue? Until the war ended.

How many were in it? Who was bandmaster? Mr. J.B. Foster.

What instruments were included? Trumpet, violin, drums.

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for. They did not wear uniforms. It played for all the dances, fairs and other things.
